title: U.S. Stocks Fall as China Covid-19 Cases Rise; Investors are worried increase in Covid infections will interrupt easing of restrictions, delaying pickup in China's growth
text:
Investors had hoped that signs of easing Covid-19 containment measures would allow for China's economic growth to pick up, also benefiting the global economy. Several Chinese cities had said they would no longer carry out mandatory mass testing and lifted the requirement for residents to show proof of a recent negative test to enter public places.

A rise in Covid-19 infections and the reporting of virus-related deaths for the first time in almost six months have caused investors to worry that China's normalization could instead be further delayed.

"All eyes are on China," said Hani Redha, a portfolio manager at PineBridge Investments. "Any attempt to reopen is going to be tricky because we know the pattern with these things: you get a spike in cases. We haven't even really got going and there are already a lot of cases."

Restaurant, retailer and Macau casino stocks listed in Hong Kong fell, while liquor makers dragged on the Chinese onshore market. Hot-pot restaurant operator Haidilao International Holding and Sands China each fell more than 7% in Hong Kong trading. The city's benchmark Hang Seng Index declined 1.9%. China's Shanghai Composite edged down 0.4%.

On the domestic front, investors were anticipating a quiet week with the Thanksgiving holiday on Thursday. The biggest event this week is Wednesday's release of the minutes of this month's Federal Reserve meeting.

Investors will be looking for clues to Fed officials' opinion on the pace of inflation, and whether it will prompt the central bank to ratchet down the pace of interest-rate increases. "It's very important for market players," said AvaTrade analyst Naeem Aslam.

In corporate news, shares of Walt Disney's jumped 8% after the entertainment giant replaced Chief Executive Bob Chapek with Robert Iger, the company's former chairman and CEO.

Shares of Imago BioSciences more than doubled after Merck agreed to acquire the developer of bone-marrow disease drugs for $1.35 billion.

Coinbase Global dropped 6.3% as the crypto market continues to struggle in the wake of the collapse of exchange FTX.

In energy markets, U.S. crude prices fell 4.9% to $76.23 a barrel, trading under $80 for the first time since September amid a darkening outlook for the global economy.

The WSJ Dollar Index, which measures the performance of the U.S. currency against a basket of others, rose 0.7%.

In bond markets, the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell to 3.796% from 3.817% Friday. Yields and prices move inversely.

Overseas, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 rose 0.2%.

In cryptocurrencies, bitcoin's dollar value lingered near $16,000 apiece. Pessimism on the outlook for digital assets has worsened following the swift collapse of cryptocurrency exchange FTX. Investors are worried that failures among other companies could be on the horizon.

Write to Caitlin Ostroff at caitlin.ostroff@wsj.com
